Literature Review:
TonB-dependent transporters (TBDTs) are integral components of the outer membrane (OM) of gram-negative bacteria, playing a crucial role in the uptake of scarce or large molecules that cannot passively diffuse through the OM. These transporters are powered by the proton motive force (PMF) and are linked to the TonB-ExbBD complex located in the inner membrane, which transduces energy to facilitate the active transport process. The complexity of this transport mechanism has been a subject of extensive research, yet many aspects remain elusive. 

The structure of TBDTs is characterized by a β-barrel domain that spans the OM and a plug domain that occludes the barrel, preventing passive diffusion of molecules. The interaction between the TonB protein and the TBDT is essential for the transport process. TonB is thought to undergo conformational changes that allow it to interact with the plug domain of the TBDT, facilitating the opening of the channel and the translocation of substrates (Noinaj et al., 2010). This interaction is energy-dependent, with the energy being derived from the PMF across the inner membrane, which is harnessed by the ExbBD complex (Celia et al., 2016).

The specificity of TBDTs for their substrates is determined by the extracellular loops of the β-barrel, which recognize and bind specific ligands. This specificity is crucial for the uptake of essential nutrients such as iron-siderophore complexes, vitamin B12, and other scarce nutrients (Schauer et al., 2008). The binding of the substrate to the TBDT triggers a series of conformational changes that are transmitted to the TonB protein, initiating the transport process (Postle and Kadner, 2003).

Recent studies have highlighted the potential of TBDTs as targets for novel antibiotic delivery systems, such as Trojan horse antibiotics. These antibiotics exploit the natural substrate specificity of TBDTs to gain entry into bacterial cells, thereby bypassing the OM permeability barrier (Braun and Braun, 2002). This approach has shown promise in overcoming antibiotic resistance, as it allows for the targeted delivery of antibiotics to bacterial cells while minimizing off-target effects (Zhang et al., 2019).

The role of TBDT-associated (lipo)proteins in the transport process has also been a focus of recent research. These proteins are thought to stabilize the TBDT structure and facilitate the interaction with the TonB protein. For example, the lipoprotein TonB-dependent receptor plug (Tbp) has been shown to play a critical role in the transport of vitamin B12 in Escherichia coli (Krewulak and Vogel, 2011). The interaction between Tbp and the TBDT is thought to enhance the efficiency of the transport process by stabilizing the open conformation of the TBDT during substrate translocation.

Despite the advances in our understanding of TBDT function, many questions remain unanswered. The exact mechanism by which energy is transduced from the TonB-ExbBD complex to the TBDT is still not fully understood. Additionally, the structural dynamics of the TBDT during the transport process are not well characterized, and further studies are needed to elucidate these mechanisms (Noinaj et al., 2012).

In conclusion, TBDTs are essential components of the bacterial OM that facilitate the uptake of essential nutrients and have potential applications in antibiotic delivery. The complex interplay between the TBDT, TonB, and associated (lipo)proteins is critical for the transport process, and further research is needed to fully understand the underlying mechanisms. Advances in structural biology and biochemistry will be crucial in unraveling the complexities of TBDT-mediated transport and in developing novel therapeutic strategies targeting these transporters.
